DOC.HEAD: Security Council Confronts Two Competing Panamanian Governments
Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to ADD Perez de Cuellar comments. Pickup 9th pvs, `Endara won...
With PM-Panama, Bjt
LaserPhoto NY12
DOC.TEXT: As the Security Council convened for an emergency debate on the U.S. invasion of Panama, the question that immediately arose was: who speaks for Panama? The council was expected to recognize a new Panamanian ambassador today, said diplomats and U.N. officials speaking privately. At issue was which government was legitimate: that of strongman Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega or Guillermo Endara's, which was installed by the U.S. troops that invaded Panama early Wednesday and smashed Noriega's forces. The United States, with help from other Western members, pressed Wednesday for recognition of a new ambassador appointed by Endara's government. Diplomats said Endara had appointed Eduardo Vallarino, a Panamanian businessman in self-imposed exile in the United States. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today the council was faced with an unprecedented situation because the upheaval occurred when Panama had no accredited U.N. ambassador to argue a case. The previous permanent representative, Leonardo Kam, was promoted to foreign minister, and no one took his place. Noriega's government is trying to have its ambassador to the European Community, Mirla Bellavita, accredited as U.N. ambassador. Perez de Cuellar said of the U.S. invasion that ``the position of the United Nations for the last 45 years is that we always regret the use of force.'' ``At the same time, I think I shouldn't forget to say that what is important as well for the United Nations is the preservation of democracy,'' he added. Endara won the presidency in Panama's national elections May 7-9. But the Noriega-controlled government nullified the results before they were announced. During Wednesday's debate, U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering said his country had exercised its right to self-defense under international law and the U.N. Charter ``in response to armed attacks by forces under the direction of Manuel Noriega.'' Panamanian soldiers shot and killed a U.S. Marine officer at a roadblock Saturday night, one day after Noriega declared ``a state of war'' existed between his country and the United States. American officials said the Marine, a lieutenant, was unarmed and that the attack on him and three fellow Americans was unprovoked. Pickering said the incident capped two years of harassment of U.S. military personnel and workers at the Panama Canal Commission. He said more than 400 U.S. personnel had been detained and 140 endangered. Pickering noted that Noriega's 1988 indictment in the United States on drug-trafficking and money-laundering charges. ``Gen. Noriega could not be permitted falsely to wrap himself in the flag of Panamanian sovereignty while the (Colombian) drug cartels with which he is allied intervene throughout this hemisphere,'' the ambassador said. ``That is aggression. It is aggression against us all, and now it is being brought to an end,'' Pickering said. ``His ruthless cabal repeatedly obstructed the will of the Panamanian people which has been expressed in (the May) free elections,'' which Noriega's candidate lost, Pickering said. The ambassadors of Nicaragua, China and the Soviet Union criticized the invasion and said U.S. troops should be withdrawn immediately. Britain and Canada's ambassadors defended the intervention, saying Noriega had provoked it. Ambassador Pierre-Louis Blanc of France agreed that the United States had been provoked, but said, ``For us, use of outside force is deplorable, whatever the circumstances.'' Panama has repeatedly come before the council to complain about allegedly provocative U.S. military maneuvers it said were intended to lay the groundwork for an invasion to topple Noriega. During council debates in April and August, Panama claimed the United States was trying to provoke confrontations in order to keep control of the Panama Canal. Under 1977 treaties, the United States will cede control of the canal to Panama at the end of 1999.
